qas.question: What was the Luftwaffe's second primary policy?

answers.text: to interfere with production in the vast industrial arms factories of the West Midlands

qas.question: Who was in command of the Luftflotte 2?
How many sorties a night was Luftflotte 3 doing?
What did the Fliegerkorps X concentrate on?
By April of 1941 about how many mines had been dropped?

context: Luftwaffe policy at this point was primarily to continue progressive attacks on London, chiefly by night attack; second, <a0_0>to interfere with production in the vast industrial arms factories of the West Midlands<a0_0/>, again chiefly by night attack; and third to disrupt plants and factories during the day by means of fighter-bombers. <a1_0>Kesselring<a1_0/>, commanding Luftflotte 2, was ordered to send 50 sorties per night against London and attack eastern harbours in daylight. Sperrle, commanding Luftflotte 3, was ordered to dispatch <a2_0>250<a2_0/> sorties per night including 100 against the West Midlands. Seeschlange would be carried out by Fliegerkorps X (10th Air Corps) which concentrated on <a3_0>mining operations against shipping<a3_0/>. It also took part in the bombing over Britain. By 19/20 April 1941, it had dropped <a4_0>3,984 mines<a4_0/>, ⅓ of the total dropped. The mines' ability to destroy entire streets earned them respect in Britain, but several fell unexploded into British hands allowing counter-measures to be developed which damaged the German anti-shipping campaign.
